questions.question: Preterm labor is defined as when the labor starts before
questions.explanation: Preterm labor is defined as when the labor starts before 37 weeks of gestation.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a risk factor for preterm labour?
questions.explanation: Progesterone intake is not a risk factor for preterm labour. Progesterone is used for prophylaxis ofpreterm labour.Risk factors for preterm labour:• Maternal history -••Previous history of spontaneous abortion or preterm delivery423• Artificial reproductive technique••Asymptomatic bacteriuria or recurrent UTISmoking• Maternal stress• Pregnancy complications -• Pre-eclampsia•Antepartum haemorrhage• PROM⚫ Overdistended uterus - polyhydramnios, multiple pregnancy•• Cervical incompetence• Uterine malformations• Intrauterine death• Maternal chronic diseases -•⚫ Hypertension• Nephritis• Diabetes• Severe anaemia• Periodontal diseasesOption A: Multifetal pregnancies are common following artificial reproductive techniques and canbe associated with preterm labour.Option B: Asymptomatic bacteriuria or bacterial vaginosis can cause spontaneous preterm labour.Option C: Chronic diseases like periodontal disease increase the risk of preterm labour.

questions.question: Late preterm births include births between
questions.explanation: Late preterm births include births between 34 to 36 weeks of gestational age.Timing of deliver Terminology<33 weeksyEarly pretermLate preterm34 to 36 weeks37 to 38 weeks39 to 40 weeksEarly termFull term424

questions.question: A 31-year-old G3P2 woman presents at 29 weeks of gestation with a blood-tinged vaginaldischarge. She is suspected to have preterm labour. Which of the following findings will nothelp confirm her diagnosis?
questions.explanation: A cervical length of 32 mm (3 cm) does not help in confirming preterm labour as it is highlyunlikely when the cervical length is >3 cm. The length of the cervix in preterm labour, asmeasured in transvaginal ultrasound is ≤2.5 cm.Preterm labor is the onset of labor before 37 completed weeks of pregnancy (less than 259 days ofgestation).Features of preterm labor:•• Uterus - regular contractions at least one in every 10 minutes, with/without pain• Cervix - dilatation >2 cm and effacement >80%• TVS - length of cervix <2.5 cm and funneling of the internal os >1 cm.• Pelvic pressure, backache, vaginal discharge or bleeding PVPredictors of preterm labor:●•Clinical predictors:History of prior preterm birth• Multiple pregnancies• Presence of genital tract infection•Symptoms of preterm labour•Biophysical predictors:•Uterine contractions ≥4/hour• Bishop score ≥4• Cervical length (TVS) ≤25 mm• Biochemical predictors:••• Fetal fibronectin (fFN) in cervical/vaginal discharge >50 ng/mL• Increased levels of IL-6, IL-8, TNF-alphaThe best predictors of preterm labor in a woman with a previous history of preterm birth are fetalfibronectin >50ng/ml and cervical length <2.5cm on TVS.

questions.question: Which of the following cannot be used to predict preterm labour in a patient having irregularuterine contractions at 30 weeks of gestation?
questions.explanation: IL-2 is not a biochemical predictor of preterm labour.Biochemical predictors of preterm labor:• Fetal fibronectin• IL 6425• IL 8• TNF°Investigations of preterm labour:••Fetal fibronectin >50 ng/mlTVS - length of cervix ≤2.5 cm• Urine culture••High vaginal swab• Maternal salivary estriol• Uterine activity monitoring

questions.question: A 30-year-old G2P1Lo woman came for a routine antenatal checkup at 20 weeks of gestation.She is worried about preterm labour as her previous baby was born preterm. What will be thetiming and cut-off limit for fetal fibronectin (fFN) assay to predict this condition?
questions.explanation: Fetal fibronectin value of >50 ng/mL in the cervicovaginal discharge between 24 and 34 weeksis predictive of preterm labor.Fibronectin is a glycoprotein that binds the fetal membranes to the decidua. It is normally foundin the cervicovaginal discharge before 22 weeks and after 37 weeks of gestation.It is measured using an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay. When the test is negative, itreassures that the delivery will not occur within the next 7 days.

questions.question: A pregnant woman presented with blood-tinged vaginal discharge at 35 weeks of gestation. Anitrazine paper test was performed on her. What is this test used to detect?

options.B: Fetal blood cells in Rh isoimmunisation

questions.explanation: The nitrazine paper test is used to detect premature rupture of membranes.The nitrazine paper test detects the pH of the secretions from the vaginal pool. It turns blue at pH>6. Amniotic fluid is slightly alkaline with a pH of 7.1 - 7.3 and vaginal secretions have a pH of4.5-6.0.False-positive nitrazine test can be seen in contamination of the discharge with blood, semen, andbacterial infections.The below image shows the nitrazine paper.4260283-0074-97pH paperPHENAPHTHAZINE PAPERBEUTLICH PHARMACEUTICALS LPFOR ULL MOISTON TESTIILIT TIRE BOREVERWITH CHART BREDMpH 4.5 5.0 5.5 6.0 6.5 7.0 7.5Option A: Fetal hemoglobin in vasa previa is detected by Apt test.Option B: Estimation of the volume of fetal blood entering the maternal circulation in Rhisoimmunisation is done by Kleihauer-Betke test.Option D: In abruptio placenta, the diagnosis is mainly based on clinical features.

questions.question: 417A sample of the vaginal fluid from the posterior fornix of a patient gave a positive nitrazinepaper test. Which of the following conditions does not give a false positive result?
questions.explanation: Oligohydramnios shows a false negative nitrazine paper test.Nitrazine paper test detects the pH of the secretions from the vaginal pool. It turns blue at pH>6. Amniotic fluid is slightly alkaline with a pH of 7.1 - 7.3 and vaginal secretions have a pH of4.5-6.0.False-positive nitrazine test can be seen in contamination of the discharge with blood, semen, andbacterial infections. False-negative nitrazine test can be seen in the case of scanty amniotic fluid.

questions.question: Transvaginal sonography in a case of clinically suspected preterm labour revealed a shortcervix and funnelling of the internal os. What is the shape of the cervix that is likely to beseen here?
questions.explanation: U-shaped cervix is seen on tranvaginal sonography (TVS) in preterm labour.On TVS, the cervix should be assessed to determine whether funnelling (internal os width >5mm) is present.The following is a TVS image showing a V-shaped cervix:Shape of cerviInferenceXT shapedNormal427Shape of cerviInferenceXY shapedV shapedU shapedurSuspicion of preterm labourFunneling of internal osIncompetent osPreterm laboTransvaginal ultrasound showingV-shaped cervix - Preterm labourGE

questions.question: A multigravida presents with preterm premature rupture of membranes. According to RCOGguidelines, which of the following antibiotics is preferred for her?
questions.explanation: According to RCOG guidelines, erythromycin is the preferred antibiotic in the case of PPROM(preterm premature rupture of membranes).Spontaneous rupture of membranes before the onset of labour between 28 to 37 weeks is calledpreterm premature rupture of membranes.If PPROM occurs between 28 to 34 weeks, prophylactic antibiotics and corticosteroids are givento the patient.

questions.question: A primigravida at 30 weeks of gestation presents with labour pains but her membranes wereintact. You decide to start her on corticosteroids and a tocolytic. Which of the following drugswill not be useful in this case?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of preterm labour with intact membranes andprogesterone is not used as a tocolytic in these cases.Progesterone can be used for the prophylaxis of preterm labour in women with a previous historyof spontaneous preterm labour.Glucocorticoid therapy is given in preterm labour when the period of gestation is <34 weeks tohasten fetal lung maturity. Short term therapy with tocolytics is given in conjunction with steroidsfor 1-3 days to delay labour for at least 48 hours or to transfer the patient to a tertiary centre (with428NICU).Tocolytics that can be given as short term therapy include:• Terbutaline•Magnesium sulphate• Indomethacin⚫ Nifedipine• Atosiban

questions.question: A primigravida at 32 weeks of gestation was admitted for management of preterm labour.Which of the following tocolytics would be preferred for this?
questions.explanation: Nifedipine is the preferred tocolytic as it has minimum maternal side effects.According to ACOG guidelines, the use of tocolytics in preterm labour does not prolong gestationbut may delay delivery upto 48 hours. Hence, short-term therapy with tocolytics is given for 1-3days to delay labour for the action of corticosteroid therapy or to transfer the patient to a tertiarycentre (with NICU).Tocolytics used in preterm labour and their side effects:TocolyticsBeta-adrenergic agonists:RitodrineTerbutalineIsoxsuprineCalcium channel blockers:NifedipineNicardipineVerapamilOxytocin antagonists:Atosiban(not approved for use in India)Magnesium sulphateCOX inhibitors: IndomethacinSulindacMaternal side effectsHeadache, palpitations, tachycardia, hypotension, pulmonary edema, cardiac failure, ARDSHypotension, headache, flushing, nauseaNausea, vomiting, chest painFlushing, perspiration, headache, muscle weakness, respiratory paralysisHeartburn, asthma, GI bleeding, thrombocytopenia, renal injury, platelet dysfunction, oligohydramniosFetal/neonatal side effectsFetal heart failure, intrauterine deathNeonatal hypoglycemia, intraventricular haemorrhageNeonatal cardiac arrest, lethargy, hypotonia, respiratory depressionConstriction of ductus arteriosus, pulmonary hypertension,intrauterine growth restriction

questions.question: Which of the following is not a contraindication for tocolysis in a patient with pretermlabour?
questions.explanation: Placenta previa is not a contraindication for tocolysis. In placenta previa, nifedipine andmagnesium sulphate are used as tocolytics.Contraindications to tocolysis:429• Chorioamnionitis• Preeclampsia/Eclampsia• Advanced labour• Fetal distress•• Intra-uterine death•Congenital anomalies not compatible with life• Pregnancy >34 weeks●Abruptio placenta

questions.question: A G3P1A1 woman presents with preterm labour at 27 weeks of gestation. She tells you thather previous child who was born preterm developed cerebral palsy. Which of the followingdrugs can you use to reduce the incidence of this condition?
questions.explanation: Magnesium sulphate has a neuroprotective effect and hence decreases the risk of developingcerebral palsy.Magnesium sulphate can be used for neuroprotection in preterm labour when the pregnancy is<32 weeks. The dose is 4 g IV over 20 mins followed by an infusion of 1 g/hr.

questions.question: A primigravida was administered tocolytics and corticosteroids for preterm labour. Thefollowing day, she suddenly started coughing and gasping for air. On examination, her BP419was 160/100 mmHg and SpO2 was 80% in room air. Which of the following drugs could havecaused this?

options.B: DexamethasoneIndomethacind) RitodrineQuestion 16:Which of the following tocolytics can cause multiple fractures in the fetus if given for aprolonged duration?a) Atosibanb) Magnesium sulphate

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute pulmonary edema which is a side effect of thetocolytic ritodrine.Acute pulmonary edema in pregnancy can be due to:•⚫ Non-cardiogenic causes -••• Pre-eclampsia• Acute haemorrhage⚫ Sepsis•Tocolysis with ritodrine and magnesium sulphate• Vigorous IV fluid therapy• Cardiogenic causesTocolytics used in preterm labour and their side effects:TocolyticsBeta-adrenergic agonists:RitodrineTerbutalineIsoxsuprineCalcium channel blockers:NifedipineNicardipineVerapamilMaternal side effectsHeadache, palpitations, tachycardia, hypotension, pulmonary edema, cardiac failure, ARDSHypotension, headache, flushing, nauseaFetal/ neonatal side effectsFetal heart failure, intrauterine deathNeonatal hypoglycemia, intraventricular haemorrhage-430TocolyticsOxytocin antagonists:Atosiban(not approved for use in India)Magnesium sulphateCOX inhibitors:IndomethacinSulindacMaternal side effectsNausea, vomiting, chest painFlushing, perspiration, headache, muscle weakness, respiratory paralysisHeartburn, asthma, GI bleeding, thrombocytopenia, renal injury, platelet dysfunction, oligohydramniosFetal/neonatal side effectsNeonatal cardiac arrest, lethargy, hypotonia, respiratory depressionConstriction of ductus arteriosus, pulmonary hypertension,intrauterine growth retardation

questions.question: Post-term pregnancy refers to pregnancy continuing beyond
questions.explanation: ACOG defines post-term pregnancy as a pregnancy continuing beyond 42 completed weeks ofgestation.For clinical purposes, a pregnancy continuing beyond 2 weeks of the expected date of delivery(> 294 days) is called a post-term pregnancy.Inaccurate LMP is the most common cause of misdiagnosis of post-term pregnancy. Hence, earlyultrasound dating is important to determine fetal gestational age.

questions.question: A woman presented for an antenatal checkup 2 weeks past her EDD. Which of the followingis not an etiological factor for her condition?
questions.explanation: Maternal stress is associated with preterm labour, not post-term pregnancy.Etiological factors of post-term pregnancy are:• Inaccurate LMP•Heredity•Primiparity• Previous prolonged pregnancy•Sedentary habitsElderly multipara431• Anencephaly• Placental sulphatase deficiency

questions.question: You have performed an artificial rupture of membranes in a primigravida for augmentation oflabour. You note the amniotic fluid to be saffron-coloured. What is the likely diagnosis?

options.B: Rh incompatibilityIntrauterine deathd) Concealed placental abruptionQuestion 20:A newborn baby was found to have wrinkled, patchy skin, a long thin body and long nails.Which of the following could be a cause for his condition?a) Placental aromatase deficiencyb) Placental progesterone deficiency

questions.explanation: Saffron-coloured amniotic fluid is seen in postmaturity.

questions.question: A G2P1L1 woman came for a routine ANC at 41 weeks of gestation. On examination, herBishop score was 2. She was admitted for fetal monitoring and induction. Which of thefollowing complications would you not anticipate in the fetus even if her pregnancy continuesfurther?
questions.explanation: In the given scenario, the pregnancy continuing further would cross 42 weeks of gestation andthus turn into a post-term pregnancy. Hypoglycemia is seen in a post-term neonate.Complications of post-term pregnancy:⚫ During labour:• Fetal hypoxia• Labour dysfunction432• Macrosomia• Shoulder dystocia•Oligohydramnios• Cord compression•Birth trauma• Meconium aspiration•Intracranial haemorrhage• Following birth:•Meconium aspiration syndrome• Hypoxia• Hypoglycemia•Polycythemia• Neonatal convulsions

questions.question: A primigravida was admitted at 42 weeks for induction of labour. Which of the followingconditions is she not at an increased risk for?
questions.explanation: The risk of post-partum haemorrhage does not increase in post-term pregnancy.Complications of post-term pregnancy are due to placental insufficiency and placental ageing. Itmanifests as placental infarcts and calcifications. During post-term pregnancy, diminishedplacental function can cause oligohydramnios.Complications of post-term pregnancy are:• During labour:• Fetal hypoxia• Labour dysfunction• Macrosomia• Shoulder dystocia•Oligohydramnios• Cord compression•Birth trauma• Meconium aspiration•Following birth:• Chemical pneumonitis, atelectasis, pulmonary hypertension (due to meconium aspiration)• Hypoxia• Hypoglycemia433• Polycythemia• Neonatal convulsions

questions.question: The term small for gestational age implies birth weight
questions.explanation: Small for gestational age implies birthweight is <10th percentile for gestational age.With respect to the size, a newborn can be appropriate, small or large for gestational age.Birth weight<10th percentileTerminologySmall for gestational age>90th percentileBetween 10th and 90th percentileLarge for gestational ageAppropriate for gestational age

questions.question: What is the normal pH of amniotic fluid?
questions.explanation: The normal pH of the amniotic fluid is 7.1 - 7.3The normal pH of the vaginal secretions is 4.5 - 5.5. In premature rupture of membranes (PROM),the pH of the vaginal secretions becomes 6 - 6.2 as the amniotic fluid mixes with it. This forms thebasis for nitrazine paper test.434
